Issues.Title: An error dialog pops up when running the winforms .net core application with .NET Core 5.0 SDK
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: NET Core SDK 5.0.100 - alpha1 5.0.100.15436
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: No

**More info:**
1. WPF .NET Core app also cannot run when targeting .NET Core 5.0.
2. Console .NET Core app can run when targeting .NET Core 5.0.

**Minimal repro:**
1. Install .NET core 5.0 SDK from: https://github.com/dotnet/core-sdk.
2. Create a Windows Forms .NET Core App and target net core 5.0.
3. Press F5.

**Actual behavior:** <!-- callstack for crashes / exceptions -->
An error dialog pops up when running the winforms .net core application.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/56662732/67556207-4d1c1180-f745-11e9-9910-e91f604af8b5.png)


**Expected behavior:**
The WinForms .NET core app can run successfully.

**Call Stack**
[Call Stack.txt](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/3771375/Call.Stack.txt)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "An error dialog pops up when running the winforms .net core application with .NET Core 5.0 SDK" (#2195)

Issues.Title: WIP: fix lock inversion
Issues.Body:
Fixes #1999

## Proposed changes

- Installing NoAssertListener and using NoAssertListener suffered from a deadlock due to lock inversion. The installation first takes the NoAssertContext lock then proceeds to install the TraceListener, which requires the TraceListenerCollection lock.

  Other threads can continue running and may be logging/asserting. As soon as the NoAssertListener is installed he will be picked up and start receiving calls. When NoAssertListener is called into the overridden methods the caller will be holding the TraceListenerCollection lock. The override now proceeds to take the NoAssertContext lock. If installation did not yet complete you have a deadlock due to lock inversion.

  Resolution is to enforce lock ordering by never taking the TraceListenerCollection lock when the NoAssertContext lock is already held. This makes installation/uninstallation more complex but prevents the deadlocks.

## Customer Impact

- None, test only

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- None, test only

### Before

- Deadlocks observed where one thread was in the NoAssertContext constructor

### After

- Deadlocks should no longer have a thread in NoAssertContext constructor

## Test methodology

- WIP

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/2184)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "WIP: fix lock inversion" (#2184)

Issues.Title: Fix NoAssertContext deadlock
Issues.Body:
The assert context listener would deadlock sometimes and wasn't particularly efficient. @weltkante discovered this in #2184 and encouraged me to rethink how to approach this.

Fixes #1999

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/2191)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Fix NoAssertContext deadlock" (#2191)

Issues.Title: The RadioButton's checked state is incorrect in runtime after setting radioButton.Select event
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: .NET Core 3.1.100-preview2-014532 from Release branch
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: **Yes**

**More Info:**
1. This is not a regression issue, it can repro from .NET Framework 2.0 to .NET Framework 4.8 latest build.
2. When comment code **rButton.Select();**, this issue cannot repro.

**Minimal repro:**
1. Create a winforms .NET core app.
2. Add the following code to the the constrator of Form1.
```
       RadioButton rButton = new RadioButton();
       rButton.Text = "rButton";
       rButton.Checked = false;
       this.Controls.Add(rButton);
       rButton.Select();
```

3. Press F5 to run the application.

**Actual behavior:** 
The RadioButton was checked.
![Current](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49627022/67537656-ef6cd280-f70e-11e9-993a-475f62b69214.png)

**Expected behavior:**
The RadioButton should not be checked.
![Expected](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49627022/67537666-f5fb4a00-f70e-11e9-85a1-c79819bb2cfe.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The RadioButton's checked state is incorrect in runtime after setting radioButton.Select event" (#2193)

Issues.Title: Flaky test: `Application_VisualStyleState_Set_ReturnsExpected` deadlock
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->

**Problem description:**

As part of tests deadlock investigation, the major deadlock causing issue was eliminated in #2191, however that uncovered a secondary issue that `MonthCalendar_CalendarDimensions_SetAreaOfTwelve_GetReturnsExpected` could deadlock as well.

**Actual behavior:** <!-- callstack for crashes / exceptions -->

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/67532139-e3821000-f710-11e9-83c8-d0352cc71b4e.png)

All but two threads appear to be waiting.

This thread is executing out code appears to be stuck sending "theme changed" messages
```
Flagged	>	71456	11	Worker Thread	<No Name>	System.Windows.Forms.dll!System.Windows.Forms.Application.SendThemeChangedRecursive

 	[Managed to Native Transition]		Annotated Frame
>	System.Windows.Forms.dll!System.Windows.Forms.Application.SendThemeChangedRecursive(System.IntPtr handle = 0x00000000000727ca, System.IntPtr lparam = 0x0000000000000000) Line 648	C#	Symbols loaded.
 	[Native to Managed Transition]		Annotated Frame
 	[Managed to Native Transition]		Annotated Frame
 	System.Windows.Forms.dll!System.Windows.Forms.Application.SendThemeChangedRecursive(System.IntPtr handle = 0x0000000000971f24, System.IntPtr lparam = 0x0000000000000000) Line 643	C#	Symbols loaded.
 	[Native to Managed Transition]		Annotated Frame
 	[Managed to Native Transition]		Annotated Frame
 	System.Windows.Forms.dll!System.Windows.Forms.Application.SendThemeChangedRecursive(System.IntPtr handle = 0x00000000002320fe, System.IntPtr lparam = 0x0000000000000000) Line 643	C#	Symbols loaded.
 	System.Windows.Forms.dll!System.Windows.Forms.Application.SendThemeChanged(System.IntPtr handle = 0x00000000002320fe, System.IntPtr extraParameter = 0x0000000000000000) Line 625	C#	Symbols loaded.
 	[Native to Managed Transition]		Annotated Frame
 	[Managed to Native Transition]		Annotated Frame
 	System.Windows.Forms.dll!System.Windows.Forms.Application.VisualStyleState.set(System.Windows.Forms.VisualStyles.VisualStyleState value = NoneEnabled) Line 609	C#	Symbols loaded.
 	System.Windows.Forms.Tests.dll!System.Windows.Forms.Tests.ApplicationTests.Application_VisualStyleState_Set_ReturnsExpected(System.Windows.Forms.VisualStyles.VisualStyleState value = NoneEnabled) Line 43	C#	Symbols loaded.
 	[Native to Managed Transition]		Annotated Frame
 	[Managed to Native Transition]		Annotated Frame
 	xunit.execution.dotnet.dll!Xunit.Sdk.TestInvoker<System.__Canon>.CallTestMethod(object testClassInstance = {System.Windows.Forms.Tests.ApplicationTests}) Line 150	C#	Non-user code. Symbols loaded.

```
And this thread I presume responsible for handling events?
```
Flagged		87564	22	Worker Thread	.NET SystemEvents	Microsoft.Win32.SystemEvents.dll!Microsoft.Win32.SystemEvents.WindowThreadProc

 	[Managed to Native Transition]		Annotated Frame
>	Microsoft.Win32.SystemEvents.dll!Microsoft.Win32.SystemEvents.WindowThreadProc()	Unknown	Non-user code. Skipped loading symbols.
 	System.Private.CoreLib.dll!System.Threading.ThreadHelper.ThreadStart_Context(object state)	Unknown	Non-user code. Skipped loading symbols.
 	System.Private.CoreLib.dll!System.Threading.ExecutionContext.RunInternal(System.Threading.ExecutionContext executionContext, System.Threading.ContextCallback callback, object state)	Unknown	Non-user code. Skipped loading symbols.
 	System.Private.CoreLib.dll!System.Threading.ThreadHelper.ThreadStart()	Unknown	Non-user code. Skipped loading symbols.

```

**Expected behavior:**

Tests don't deadlock

**Minimal repro:**

Uncomment tests and run `build -test`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Flaky test: `Application_VisualStyleState_Set_ReturnsExpected` deadlock" (#2192)

Issues.Title: Porting Narrator announcement for StringCollectionEditor items
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes #2188 


## Proposed changes

- Adding StringCollectionEditorTextBox class derived from standard TextBox with enhanced accessibility (UI Automation and UI Notification) support.
- Adding UIA notification announcement for item navigation within StringCollectionEditorTextBox.

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- Visually impaired user will be able to distinguish the currently edited/selected/navigated string item within StringCollectionEditor control.

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Minimal

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before

No announcement for SringCollectionEditor navigation.

### After

SringCollectionEditor item navigation is announced properly.


## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Manual testing.
- Automation tests (to run)
- Unit tests (to be implemented)

## Accessibility testing  <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

<!--
     Microsoft prioritizes making our products accessible. 
     WinForms has a key role in allowing developers to create accessible apps. 
     
     When submitting a change which impacts UI in any way, including adding new UI or
     modifying existing controls the developer needs to run the Accessibility Insights
     tool (https://accessibilityinsights.io/) and verify that there are no changes or
     regressions. 
     
     The developer should run the Fast Pass over the impacted control(s) and provide
     a snapshot of the passing results along with before/after snapshots of the UI.
     More info: (https://accessibilityinsights.io/docs/en/web/getstarted/fastpass)
  -->

There is no UI changes but changes in accessibility providers: IAccessible is partially changed to UI Automation.

Issues.Title: Port Narrator announcement for StringCollectionEditor items
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 3.1
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: Yes

<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->

**Problem description:**
There is no screen reader announcement for item navigation and selecting in StringCollectionEditor UI.

**Actual behavior:**
Narrator does not announce the StringCollectionEditor item when navigating up and down thru the items list.

**Expected behavior:**
Narrator announces the item when focus goes to item when navigating using keyboard/mouse.

**Minimal repro:**
* Create WinForms app with ComboBox or another list control which collection can be edited using StringCollectionEditor.
* Add PropertyGrid control to the form and associate its selected object with previously added ComboBox.
* Run the app try to edit the collection of items (add few items and navigate up/down using keyboard within StringCollectionEditor textbox.
* Observe no announcement when navigation.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Port Narrator announcement for StringCollectionEditor items" (#2188)

Issues.Title: Necessary CodeDomSerializers not ported to WinForms
Issues.Body:
The follow `CodeDomSerializer`s have not been ported to .NET Core WinForms, and are needed for designer scenarios:

* `System.ComponentModel.Design.Serialization.LocalizationCodeDomSerializer`
* `System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlCodeDomSerializer`
* `System.Windows.Forms.Design.DataGridViewRowCollectionCodeDomSerializer`
* `System.Windows.Forms.Design.TableLayoutPanelCodeDomSerializer`
* `System.Windows.Forms.Design.TableLayoutControlCollectionCodeDomSerializer`
* `System.Windows.Forms.Design.ToolStripMenuItemCodeDomSerializer`

Everything in WinForms that has a `DesignerSerializerAttribute` should be audited to ensure that the type specified by the attribute actually exists.

cc @merriemcgaw
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Necessary CodeDomSerializers not ported to WinForms" (#2185)

Issues.Title: The empty DataGridView control cannot get a blue Narrator rectangle, just get the focus dot line
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: (.NET Core SDK 3.1 Preview 2 3.1.100.14533)
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: Yes

<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->

**Problem description:**
The empty DataGridView control cannot get a blue Narrator rectangle, just get the focus dot line, so no any announcement about the empty dataGridView.
But when adding some columns to the DataGridView, the blue rectangle will on the currently specific cells with corresponding announcement by Narrator reading. Maybe this issue is by design, just report here and find the final confirmation from you guys.

This issue also can reproduce with latest .NET Framework 4.8 project.

**Actual behavior:** <!-- callstack for crashes / exceptions -->
The empty DataGridView control cannot get a blue Narrator rectangle, just get the focus dot line.

**Expected behavior:**
The empty DataGridView control should get a blue Narrator rectangle.

**Minimal repro:**
1.	Run the attached app,
2.	Launch the Narrator and tab to navigate to the controls on the form.
3.	Observe the narrator blue rectangle between controls and DataGridView.
[WindowsFormsApp3.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/3766270/WindowsFormsApp3.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The empty DataGridView control cannot get a blue Narrator rectangle, just get the focus dot line" (#2178)
